As a manager, I believe that having a precise answer to every question a subordinate may raise about their work is not necessarily a requirement for being a good manager. While having a deep understanding of the work and being able to provide accurate answers to complex questions is important, there are other qualities that are equally crucial for effective management.

Firstly, good managers must be able to communicate effectively, both verbally and in writing. They should be able to articulate their ideas clearly and concisely, and be able to listen actively to the concerns and ideas of their team members. Being able to build strong relationships with subordinates is crucial for creating a positive work environment and fostering open communication.

Secondly, managers should be able to lead by example and demonstrate the behaviors and values they expect from their team. This includes being punctual, reliable, and consistent in their work habits, as well as being proactive in identifying and solving problems. By consistently setting a good example, managers can inspire their team to do the same, and create a culture of accountability and responsibility.

Finally, good managers must be able to adapt to changing circumstances and prioritize effectively. In today's fast-paced business environment, being able to pivot quickly and make decisions under pressure is essential for success. Managers who can balance competing priorities and make informed decisions, even in uncertain situations, are better equipped to lead their teams to success.

In conclusion, while having a precise answer to every question may be desirable in some situations, it is not the only factor that determines a good manager. Effective managers must be able to communicate well, lead by example, and adapt to changing circumstances. As a female manager in a mid-sized company in Shanghai, I believe that these qualities are essential for creating a positive work environment and driving business success.
